results.title: How about you?
results.brief_description: A sex eductional film which uses a factual but informal style. Discusses social attitudes towards sexuality and shows the effectiveness of a variety of contraceptive methods (somewhat out of date!). It also discusses women’s issues and the freedom of women to own and control their own body. Please note this film was made in 1972 and pre-dates AIDS.

results.title: How about a break; You can do it
results.creator_credit: Suzanne Baker, Film Australia and Debby Kingsland
results.brief_description: Two short films in one. The first shows the frustration’s faced by an ‘average’ housewife, the second, the benefits of engaging in recreational activities outside the home. Cast includes Max Cullen, Julie Dawson, Kate Whiteley, Beth Whiteley.

results.title: How a Child Grows (Captioned)
results.brief_description: This documentary follows a baby for the first five days of her life in a Sydney hospital. We see the various tests and examinations that the baby undergoes. The medical staff discuss the main concerns of the parents in these first important days: feeding, jaundice and any behaviour by the baby that doesn’t seem absolutely “normal” to the parents. The mother describes her feelings and reactions during these first emotional days with her new baby.

results.title: How a cheque book works
results.creator_credit: Andrew J. Helgeson, Austral Pacific Productions, National Bank of Australia and Raymond Leach
results.brief_description: An animated film in which a young boy’s enquiries about money lead to a lesson on the uses of a cheque book. During a visit to the bank the role of the manager, and other bank services are explained.

results.title: How's it going?
results.brief_description: The four cases that make up this film deal with an important management activity: the interview. They have been designed to permit investigation of basic interviewing principles and techniques for appraising employee performance. Specifically, they serve as a springboard for analysing four goals of both interviewer and interviewee: understanding, agreement, action and learning. Methods for dealing with interview problems. The four cases are: 1. More than paperwork. 2. Give and take. 3. Means to an end. 4. The way ahead.

results.title: Hoverport
results.creator_credit: Robert Kruger, National Coal Board and Stanley Goulder
results.brief_description: The building of Britain’s first international port for hovercraft at Pegwell Bay near Ramsgate, on reclaimed land at the water’s edge. Shows the stages of reclamation and construction through adverse conditions in winter, and finally the hovercraft taking off for a brisk 70 mph run across the English channel to Calais.

results.title: Hovercraft
results.creator_credit: John Read, Brith Broadcasting Corporation and Peter Bennet Stone
results.brief_description: The story of Christopher Cockerell and of his invention, the Hovercraft. Tells how he developed the principle while running a small boatyard on the Norfolk Broads and how after many attempts the idea was adapted by industry. Describes the construction and operation of the latest British Hovercraft made by four different firms, and a high speed journey along the coast of the Isle of Wight.

results.title: Hoverbug
results.creator_credit: George H. Brown, Fanfare Films and Jan Darnley-Smith
results.brief_description: Young Dick and Jenny Brewster are trying to build a small hovercraft to enter into a race. Mr Watts, an eccentric inventor, offers his help. Charley Guthridge and his mate Sidney plot to prevent Dick and Jenny from building their home-made hovercraft. On the day of the big race, Dick and Jenny stuggle to take the lead and beat their opponents. Stars Jill Riddick; John Trayhorn; Francis Attard; Gary Cann; Arthur Howard; Michael Balfour; Jan Butlin; Peter Myers; Cardew Robinson; Michael Segal; Harold Goodwin; Marianne Stone; and Janet Waldron.
